title: More About Me
text:
Where I’m From
I was born on Maui, Hawaii and I lived there until I was five. Then, I grew up in a small town called Brookdale nestled in the Santa Cruz mountains! I was lucky enough to live in two places with spectacular nature. My upbringing definitely fostered a love and respect for the environment, inspiring me to get my degree in environmental studies.

Maui









Brookdale










My Current Favorite Plant and Animal
I am currently obsessed with redwood trees, and baby deer!





My Current Favorite Book
I recently read Sharks in the time of Saviors by Kawai Strong Washburn, and would love to chat about it with anyone willing to listen!

title: Restoration and Rest areas at UCSB
text:
I am a student worker for the Cheadle Center for Biodiversity and Ecological Restoration. In this, we remove invasive plants using different techniques, such as solarization, manual removal, controlled burns, and careful use of grass specific herbicide. We also collect seeds from local native plants in order to spread to other areas around campus and increase the local plant biodiversity. I have learned a lot about the different native plants in the Isla Vista area, as well as useful land management strategies.


{=html}  






This is where I park to work at the Ellwood Marine Terminal! This is one of the newer sites, where we are planting for the butterfly grove as well as plants that will act as filtration for the riparian zone nearby.



This is where most of my work takes place, as my boss is the Lagoon steward. Here, we are mostly removing invasive species.




This site was burned in the Summer of 2024, right before I started working for CCBER. It was burned with the intent to heat and kill the invasive grasses and their seeds, and to test out different treatments for restoration. Over the course of this school year, we have monitored how the different subplots (high native seeding, low seed, no seed) are blooming after the burn, as well as the recovery of shrubs that survived the burn. There is a control plot a thatch-removed plot, and a grass-specific herbicide plot nearby that are monitored simultaneously. We also remove any invasive plants that popped up after the burn.




This was the first site I worked on with CCBER, so it’s near and dear to my heart. Lots of planting and weeding!



This project has a lot of sky and bush lupines, which have become my favorite flowers! Also lots of planting, weeding, and seed collecting.
















An amazing spot to tidepool and surf! I didn’t know about this place until my second year at UCSB, but now I can’t get enough!










This grassy park is a lovely place to tan, do homework outside, and people watch.



Another lovely grassy area to hang out in Isla Vista, I usually stop here on my walk to Dev’s.



Where I fell in love with surfing my freshman year. I was able to see bioluminescence here and I have never felt more like a mermaid. .



The best place to study! A beautiful outdoor ocean view deck.

title: Restoration and Rest areas at UCSB
section: flower = CCBER sites, star = rest areas at ucsb
text:
flower = CCBER sites, star = rest areas at ucsb
{=html}  
Flowers: Sites I work at with CCBER
From Left to Right:
Ellwood Marine Terminal:
This is where I park to work at the Ellwood Marine Terminal! This is one of the newer sites, where we are planting for the butterfly grove as well as plants that will act as filtration for the riparian zone nearby.
Lagoon Island:
This is where most of my work takes place, as my boss is the Lagoon steward. Here, we are mostly removing invasive species.
Burn Plot:
This site was burned in the Summer of 2024, right before I started working for CCBER. It was burned with the intent to heat and kill the invasive grasses and their seeds, and to test out different treatments for restoration. Over the course of this school year, we have monitored how the different subplots (high native seeding, low seed, no seed) are blooming after the burn, as well as the recovery of shrubs that survived the burn. There is a control plot a thatch-removed plot, and a grass-specific herbicide plot nearby that are monitored simultaneously. We also remove any invasive plants that popped up after the burn.
Campus Point:
This was the first site I worked on with CCBER, so it’s near and dear to my heart. Lots of planting and weeding!
Henley Gate:
This project has a lot of sky and bush lupines, which have become my favorite flowers! Also lots of planting, weeding, and seed collecting.
Stars: Some of my favorite rest spots on/around campus
From Left to Right:
Deverux:
An amazing spot to tidepool and surf! I didn’t know about this place until my second year at UCSB, but now I can’t get enough!
Del Playa Park
This grassy park is a lovely place to tan, do homework outside, and people watch.
Window to the Sea Park
Another lovely grassy area to hang out in Isla Vista, I usually stop here on my walk to Dev’s.
Campus point (again)
Where I fell in love with surfing my freshman year. I was able to see bioluminescence here and I have never felt more like a mermaid. .
Bren Hall deck
The best place to study! A beautiful outdoor ocean view deck.

title: CCBER Sites
text:
I am a student worker for the Cheadle Center for Biodiversity and Ecological Restoration. In this, we remove invasive plants using different techniques, such as solarization, manual removal, controlled burns, and careful use of grass specific herbicide. We also collect seeds from local native plants in order to spread to other areas around campus and increase the local plant biodiversity. I have learned a lot about the different native plants in the Isla Vista area, as well as useful land management strategies.

Ellwood Marine Terminal:
This is where I park to work at the Ellwood Marine Terminal! This is one of the newer sites, where we are planting coast live oaks and eucalyptus trees for the butterfly grove as well as other native plants that will act as filtration for the riparian zone nearby.


Lagoon Island:
This is where most of my work takes place, as my boss is the Lagoon steward. Here, we are mostly removing invasive species such as bromus diandrus, festuca myuros, erodium botrys, lysimachia arvensis, and more.



Burn Plot:
This site was burned in the Summer of 2024, right before I started working for CCBER. It was burned with the intent to heat and kill the invasive grasses and their seeds, and to test out different treatments for restoration. Over the course of this school year, we have monitored how the different subplots (high native seeding, low seed, no seed) are blooming after the burn, as well as the recovery of shrubs that survived the burn. There is a control plot a thatch-removed plot, and a grass-specific herbicide plot nearby that are monitored simultaneously. We also remove any invasive plants that popped up after the burn.



Campus Point:
This was the first site I worked on with CCBER, so it’s near and dear to my heart. Lots of planting and weeding!


Henley Gate:
This project has a lot of sky and bush lupines, which have become my favorite flowers! Also lots of planting, weeding, and seed collecting.
